This would go for certain other musical forms as well.

I kind of agree in theory, but in practice am not always sure where the line should be drawn.

Consider some arguments against rock music (specifically):

The "and Roll" in "Rock n' Roll" referred to fornication: 

> Many people don't know that the term rock-n-roll was also a slang word for [the reproductive act] in the late 1940s and early 1950s. It was particularly used by teens or the younger people in those days similar to the way people today use the word "freak" [or maybe, hook up?]. https://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=rock-n-roll

Many lyrics promote sin or godlessness (I think everyone agrees these can be a clear issue)

The culture of rock has promoted open rebellion to authority (sins of pride)

Culture of rock has promoted sins of drunkenness ("sex, drugs, and rock 'n roll")

Prominent rock musicians like the Beatles and Led Zeppelin's members have dabbled with the occult or used occult imagery

The sound of rock is aggressive rather than promoting virtues of meekness and peacefulness

The rhythms of rock are said to be sensual or incite lust and encourage people to engage in the reproductive act

Rock can encourage unbridled passion, which can lead to sin (of too much anger, leading to acts of violence like in mosh pits or outside of them, or of too much sadness, which can lead to sins of despair or hopelessness)

Rock musicians have created a culture that pushed anti-Christian political and religious values

Heavy metal rock music was used to torture people by the military: https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-40090809

I think you get the idea (mention more points if I forgot something that should be mentioned?)

Other genres like techno and rap might have the same kind of issues. Rock comes from jazz and I know some conservatives were even against jazz. The Nazis thought jazz was "degenerate art", I think: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Degenerate_music I imagine other non-Nazi conservatives were also against music like this for less controversial reasons (they just thought the music was immoral).

> Degenerate music (German: Entartete Musik, German pronunciation: [ɛntˈaʁtɛtə muˈziːk]) was a label applied in the 1930s by the Nazi government in Germany to certain forms of music that it considered harmful or decadent.

In the same vein, certain books have been banned throughout history for promoting "subversive" ideas: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_books_banned_by_governments

Regardless if the books ought to be banned or not, we might agree that their contents at times promoted sin and immorality and that they were "bad books".

Even some classical pieces might be subject to the same problems, like "modern" classical forms that are chaotic (maybe like "serialism" pieces? https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serialism)

With rock, I think the lyrics could be a clear problem, and maybe some of the drums. A counter-example would be something like "Christian rock" - is this a contradiction, like "Satanic Christianity"? Moreover, do you think God wants people to be making rock music?

In contrast, music approved for church might be an example of music that wouldn't be problematic - if there are doubts about rock music, would it be better to try to find music you have no doubts about?

Are you persuaded by rock music and other musics being bad, or if not what is your problem with it?

> How is that immodest?

I'd have to do the research again, the flappers started rebelling with shorter skirts, then I think pants were seen as a sign of rebellion. It's been the clothing style of a rebellious feminist culture.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flapper

> Flappers were a generation of young Western women in the 1920s who wore short skirts (just at the knee was short for that time period), bobbed their hair, listened to jazz, and flaunted their disdain for what was then considered acceptable behavior. Flappers were seen as brash for wearing excessive makeup, drinking alcohol, smoking cigarettes in public, driving automobiles, treating [reproduction] in a casual manner, and otherwise flouting social [and reproductive] norms.[1]

[The History Of Women Wearing Pants As Power Symbol](https://www.huffpost.com/entry/the-history-of-women-wearing-pants-as-power-symbol_n_5a99bb95e4b0a0ba4ad34fe7)

> Off the runway, retailer Ann Taylor is launching its “Pants Are Power” campaign on March 1, which, the company says, “commemorates the evolution of pants not only in fashion, but as a symbol of equality for women,” and making the question of “who wears the pants?” in a relationship seem more than metaphorical.

> Of course, women wearing pants is only newly socially acceptable (in a society controlled by the patriarchy), relatively speaking. Joan of Arc famously cross-dressed, wearing men’s armor in the 15th century as a deterrent to rape (and was eventually burned at the stake in part because of this). By 1850, Amelia Bloomer, a women’s rights activist, popularized the “bloomer” pant, those baggy, knee- or ankle-length trousers Elizabeth Smith Miller created. By the 20th century, women’s pants were appropriate for “occasional dressing only,” worn at designated times as hostess pajamas or bicycling pants, Emma McClendon, associate costume curator at The Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York, tells Yahoo Lifestyle. By the 1920s and 30s, celebrities like Marlene Dietrich dared to wear full pantsuits to movie premieres (Dietrich’s came courtesy Gabrielle Chanel), and the “most daring thing about Katharine Hepburn” was her pants.

> McClendon points out that as celebrities, both of those women could get away with wearing androgynous looks without repercussions, while ordinary women elsewhere would have been fined, thanks to laws enacted by men. In France, women needed permission to “dress like a man” to work or ride bicycles or horses, a law that remained intact until 2013 (though it hadn’t been seriously enforced in more than a century.) In 1939, a Los Angeles woman went to jail for wearing slacks to court, the judge citing them as a distraction from the ongoing legal business at hand. You get the idea.

If it doesn't apply, it may be because there is a legit double standard and women and men are different. But it also might be the case that men are criticized for wearing women's dress, like that whole Harry Styles incident of him wearing a dress.

I feel that's unfair to say as I tried to detail the logical reasons why I thought the information I saw would lead me to conclude there are problems with rock music.

> How is that immodest?

I'd have to do the research again, the flappers started rebelling with shorter skirts, then I think pants were seen as a sign of rebellion. It's been the clothing style of a rebellious feminist culture.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flapper

> Flappers were a generation of young Western women in the 1920s who wore short skirts (just at the knee was short for that time period), bobbed their hair, listened to jazz, and flaunted their disdain for what was then considered acceptable behavior. Flappers were seen as brash for wearing excessive makeup, drinking alcohol, smoking cigarettes in public, driving automobiles, treating [reproduction] in a casual manner, and otherwise flouting social [and reproductive] norms.[1]

[The History Of Women Wearing Pants As Power Symbol](https://www.huffpost.com/entry/the-history-of-women-wearing-pants-as-power-symbol_n_5a99bb95e4b0a0ba4ad34fe7)

> Off the runway, retailer Ann Taylor is launching its “Pants Are Power” campaign on March 1, which, the company says, “commemorates the evolution of pants not only in fashion, but as a symbol of equality for women,” and making the question of “who wears the pants?” in a relationship seem more than metaphorical.

> Of course, women wearing pants is only newly socially acceptable (in a society controlled by the patriarchy), relatively speaking. Joan of Arc famously cross-dressed, wearing men’s armor in the 15th century as a deterrent to rape (and was eventually burned at the stake in part because of this). By 1850, Amelia Bloomer, a women’s rights activist, popularized the “bloomer” pant, those baggy, knee- or ankle-length trousers Elizabeth Smith Miller created. By the 20th century, women’s pants were appropriate for “occasional dressing only,” worn at designated times as hostess pajamas or bicycling pants, Emma McClendon, associate costume curator at The Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York, tells Yahoo Lifestyle. This would go for certain other musical forms as well.

I kind of agree in theory, but in practice am not always sure where the line should be drawn.

Consider some arguments against rock music (specifically):

The "and Roll" in "Rock n' Roll" referred to fornication: 

> Many people don't know that the term rock-n-roll was also a slang word for [the reproductive act] in the late 1940s and early 1950s. It was particularly used by teens or the younger people in those days similar to the way people today use the word "freak" [or maybe, hook up?]. https://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=rock-n-roll

Many lyrics promote sin or godlessness (I think everyone agrees these can be a clear issue)

The culture of rock has promoted open rebellion to authority (sins of pride)

Culture of rock has promoted sins of drunkenness ("sex, drugs, and rock 'n roll")

Prominent rock musicians like the Beatles and Led Zeppelin's members have dabbled with the occult or used occult imagery

The sound of rock is aggressive rather than promoting virtues of meekness and peacefulness

The rhythms of rock are said to be sensual or incite lust and encourage people to engage in the reproductive act

Rock can encourage unbridled passion, which can lead to sin (of too much anger, leading to acts of violence like in mosh pits or outside of them, or of too much sadness, which can lead to sins of despair or hopelessness)

Rock musicians have created a culture that pushed anti-Christian political and religious values

Heavy metal rock music was used to torture people by the military: https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-40090809

I think you get the idea (mention more points if I forgot something that should be mentioned?)

Other genres like techno and rap might have the same kind of issues. Rock comes from jazz and I know some conservatives were even against jazz. The Nazis thought jazz was "degenerate art", I think: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Degenerate_music I imagine other non-Nazi conservatives were also against music like this for less controversial reasons (they just thought the music was immoral).

> Degenerate music (German: Entartete Musik, German pronunciation: [ɛntˈaʁtɛtə muˈziːk]) was a label applied in the 1930s by the Nazi government in Germany to certain forms of music that it considered harmful or decadent.

In the same vein, certain books have been banned throughout history for promoting "subversive" ideas: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_books_banned_by_governments

Regardless if the books ought to be banned or not, we might agree that their contents at times promoted sin and immorality and that they were "bad books".

Even some classical pieces might be subject to the same problems, like "modern" classical forms that are chaotic (maybe like "serialism" pieces? https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serialism)

With rock, I think the lyrics could be a clear problem, and maybe some of the drums. A counter-example would be something like "Christian rock" - is this a contradiction, like "Satanic Christianity"? Moreover, do you think God wants people to be making rock music?

In contrast, music approved for church might be an example of music that wouldn't be problematic - if there are doubts about rock music, would it be better to try to find music you have no doubts about?

Are you persuaded by rock music and other musics being bad, or if not what is your problem with it?
